newstandard.title: Common ISDN API (CAPI) v2
newstandard.applicability: The above standards are applicable to systems requiring digital, circuit switched services. The ISDN standards cover a telecommunications area analogous to the existing voice telephony network but operating digital signalling and capable of much higher data rates. ISDN circuits offer the user the ability to dial another ISDN user (using ITU-T E.164 ISDN numbering standard) and to use the enhanced data capacity in very flexible ways. ISDN is best viewed as a data pipeline which, once a connection has been established between two users, may operate a variety of protocols and carry all types of data, including voice and image. Although ISDN was originally implemented in different ways in Europe there is now a standard, Euro-ISDN, created by the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI), to which all European nations have subscribed and which now covers most of the population of Europe. The Basic user-network interface offers the user two 64kbps 'B' or Bearer channels. These may be used individually for conventional data communications or may be grouped together to give an aggregate data capacity of 128kbps for applications like restricted video. There is also a 16kbps 'D' channel which the ISDN network uses to control the operation of the 'B' channels. Euro-ISDN specifies the use of 64kbps circuit switching or 3.1kHz speech over 'B' channels but will progress to cover X.31 (X.25 over ISDN) over 'B' and 'D' channels, along with 7 KHz speech. In fact, some European PTTs are already offering an X.25 packet switching service to ISDN subscribers based on the 'D' channel. The Primary rate user-interface offers the subscriber thirty 64kbps 'B' channels and, as with the Basic interface, these may be operated singly or grouped together to service users at the termination point. The Primary rate also features a 64kbps 'D' control channel. Corporate subscribers with more than just a small number of users will be more likely to use a Primary rate interface. The thirty 'B' channels can aggregate up to a 2.048Mbps connection.

newstandard.title: CDIF - CASE Data Interchange Format - Overview
newstandard.applicability: The CDIF family of standards is primarily designed as a data interchange format to serve as a standard for the exchange of information between CASE tools. It assumes that two or more tools may interface asynchronously with each other and will transfer information from one to another via “CDIF files.” The type of information that may be contained in these files is defined by the CDIF conceptual models.

newstandard.title: Digital cellular telecommunications system (Phase 2+) (GSM); Full rate speech, Transcoding, version 8.1.1:1999
newstandard.applicability: GSM 06.10 specifies the detailed mapping between input blocks of 160 speech samples in 13 bit uniform PCM format to encoded blocks of 260 bits and from encoded blocks of 260 bits to output blocks of 160 reconstructed speech samples. The sampling rate is 8000 samples/s leading to an average bit rate for the encoded bit stream of 13 kbit/s. The encoding scheme is the so-called Regular Pulse Excitation Long Term prediction Linear Predictive Coder, here-after referred as RPE-LTP. The document also specifies the conversion between A- and u-law (PCS 1900) PCM and 13 bit uniform PCM. The second document specifies the speech codec to be used for the GSM half rate channel.

newstandard.title: Distributed Interactive Simulation - Application Protocols
newstandard.applicability:
DIS defines an infrastructure for linking simulations of various types at multiple locations to create realistic virtual worlds for the simulation of highly interactive activities. This infrastructure brings together systems built for separate purposes, heterogeneous technologies, and products from different vendors and permits them to interoperate. DIS exercises are intended to support a mixture of virtual entities (human-in-the-loop simulators), live entities (operational platforms and test and evaluation systems), and constructive entities (CGF: computer generated forces: wargames and other automated simulations).
Most of the DIS standard definitions are focused on the flow of information between simulations in order to make them interoperable. These definitions include an identification of data items, a common representation of these data items, the assembly of these data items into networked messages called Protocol Data Units (PDU), the processing that must be done before emitting and after receiving PDUs, and the key algorithms and representations that must be known and shared by all DIS participants. STANAG 4482:1995 covers these IEEE standards.

newstandard.title: Federate Interface Specification
newstandard.applicability:
The High Level Architecture (HLA) has been developed with the objective of providing a common architecture applicable across all classes of simulation to support simulation interoperability and reuse. The HLA is defined by the following three standards:
Framework and Rules - IEEE Standard P1516: The HLA rules describe the responsibilities of federates (simulations, supporting utilities, or interfaces to live systems) and federations (sets of federates working together to support distributed applications). The rules comprise a set of underlying technical principles for the HLA. For federations, the rules address the requirement for a federation object model (FOM), object ownership and representation, and data exchange. For federates, the rules require a simulation object model (SOM), time management in accordance with the HLA Runtime Infrastructure (RTI) time management services, and certain required functionality and constraints on attribute ownership and updates.
Federate Interface Specification - IEEE Standard P1516.1: In the HLA, federates interact with an RTI (analogous to a special-purpose distributed operating system) to establish and maintain a federation and to support efficient information exchange among simulations and other federates. The HLA interface specification defines the nature of these interactions, which are arranged into sets of basic RTI services.
Object Model Template (OMT) Specification - IEEE Standard P1516.2: The HLA requires simulations (and other federates) and federations to each have an object model describing the entities, not necessarily platform entities, represented in the simulations and the data to be exchanged across the federation. The HLA object model template prescribes the method for recording the information in the object models, to include objects, attributes, interactions, and parameters, but it does not define the specific data (e.g., vehicles, unit types) that will appear in the object models.

newstandard.title: Security Architecture Framework
newstandard.applicability:
The standard provides different service interfaces for key management, secure data exchange, and security management.
Security management may be expanded to include fault, performance and configuration management as well. In addition, IEEE P802.2 is considering an optional security sub-layer for logical link control.

newstandard.title: Domain names - concepts and facilities
newstandard.applicability: The primary goal of the directory service DNS is to provide a consistent name space used for referring to system resources in such a manner that the name does not require network identifiers, addresses, routes or similar information. DNS can be considered as a large, distributed mailing list which has 3 major components consisting of the name space, name servers and name resolvers.

newstandard.title: Models of Policy Based Routing
SNMP Structure of Management Information (SMI)
newstandard.applicability: SNMP is a protocol used to exchange management information between a Management-manager and Management-agents. An agent manages an object (system, device, etc.) on behalf of the Manager. The basic responsibility of an agent is to keep information about the objects. The agent stores the information and then responds to a manager request or can generate unsolicited responses. By placing the brunt of the processing on the Manager side, able to limit the agent to a few easily deployed functions. As with CMIP, ASN.1 is used to define object classes, which are documented in the appropriate TCP/IP MIB (RFC 1213:1991), and in other more specialised MIBs that address such network components as Token Ring, FDDI and particular routers.

newstandard.title: Uniform Resource Locators (URL)
newstandard.applicability:
The Uniform Resource Locators (URLs) of the form “HTTP://[ ... ]”, relative resource pointers or “MAILTO:[Email address]” the syntax and semantics of formalized information for location and access of resources via the Internet.. The URL is used by e.g. web-browsers and the HTTP protocol.
The syntax of 'mailto' URLs is extended to allow creation of more RFC 2822 messages by allowing the URL to express additional header and body fields.
RFC 2396 describes a "superset" of operations that can be applied to URI. It consists of both a grammar and a description of basic functionality for URI. To understand what is a valid URI, both the grammar and the associated description have to be studied. Some of the functionality described is not applicable to all URI schemes, and some operations are only possible when certain media types are retrieved using the URI, regardless of the scheme used.

newstandard.title: The LDAP Application Program Interface
newstandard.applicability: The Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP), developed for use over the Internet, is far more widely used than its X.500 equivalent DAP. LDAP support is becoming an integral component of a range of user platforms including Microsoft's Windows 98 and 2000. It is commonly available for UNIX environments as well as for use with X.400 and Internet based E-mail systems. LDAP is a variant of the full DAP and was originally intended by its creators to provide a lightweight complement to full DAP. Whilst DAP is much richer in functionality than LDAP, LDAP has gained considerable support in the commercial world. A number of vendors have made their proprietary directories LDAP-accessible and believe this to be a satisfactory approach for many of their customers. However, LDAP remains a simple access protocol only, and does not provide the protocols necessary for the full Directory service such as will be required by large military organisations, (note: this was one of the reasons why ACP133 currently mandates DAP). The use of LDAP in military systems is still subject to debate as there are both functional and security issues to be faced, (e.g. the US Defense Messaging System mandates DAP). However, LDAP performs a useful role in the provision of simple directory access from end-user networks

newstandard.title: SMTP Service Extensions
newstandard.applicability: In ARPANET, SMTP has been designed for sending messages containing ASCII text only. SMTP is part of the Internet protocol suite (TCP/IP). Although SMTP is text based, used in conjunction with the Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME) as defined in RFC's 2045:1996-2049:1996 and BCP0013, transfer of multipart, multimedia and binary data can be achieved. SMTP should only be considered where X.400 solutions are not consistent with the system requirements.

newstandard.title: Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol (TCP/IP) (IP Version 6)
newstandard.applicability: TCP/IP provides for a reliable, connection-oriented, end-to-end transport service on top of an unreliable network that can lose, garble, store and duplicate packets (in OSI terms a type 'C' network). In this, TCP resembles the OSI Transport Protocol class 4 (TP4) but major differences exist in features like the handling of collisions, addressing format, quality of service, the use of user data during set-up of a connection, the handling of 'important data', the absence of piggybacking in TP4, kind of message streams, flow control handling, window numbering scheme and connection release. TCP also offers some services that in OSI are positioned as 'session-layer' services. Associated with TCP is a network layer protocol called 'Internet Protocol' or 'IP'. TCP/IP can support OSI upper layer applications by employing RFC 2126:1997.

newstandard.title: DEFLATE Compressed Data Format Specification version 1.3
newstandard.applicability: An open standard for compression and decompression used widely for PC download archives, ZIP was developed by Phil Katz for his DOS-based program PKZip, and it is is now widely used on Windows-based programs such as WinZip and Drag and Zip. The file extension given to ZIP files is .zip.

newstandard.title: GZIP file format specification version 4.3
newstandard.applicability: An open standard for compression and decompression used widely for PC download archives, ZIP was developed by Phil Katz for his DOS-based program PKZip, and it is is now widely used on Windows-based programs such as WinZip and Drag and Zip. The file extension given to ZIP files is .zip.

newstandard.title: SMTP Service Extension for Remote Message Queue Starting
newstandard.applicability:
eSMTP defines an extension to the SMTP service, which allows an SMTP client to specify
that delivery status notifications (DSNs) should be generated under certain conditions,
whether such notifications should return the contents of the message, and
additional information, to be returned with a DSN, that allows the sender to identify both the recipient(s) for which the DSN was issued, and the transaction in which the original message was sent.

newstandard.title: Simple Network Time Protocol (SNTP) Version 4 for IPv4, IPv6 and OSI
newstandard.applicability: RFC 2030:1996, SNTP (Simple Network Time Protocol), uses NTP (Network Time Protocol) to provide distributed time services but is less accurate than NTP. It is recommended for use in all cases except where high precision is required. RFC 1305:1992, NTP, version 3, defines a standard format for accessing time services. It has a precision of 50 microseconds or better. NTP also provides several optional security services (e.g. et uses encryption to provide integrity and authentication). Confidentiality and non-repudiation are not supported. These IETF standards are applicable to systems requiring interoperability of time related information over a network (e.g. for enabling the time-stamping of files held on a file-server to be co-ordinated between networked clients accessing the files).

newstandard.title: SMTP Service Extension for Returning Enhanced Error Codes
newstandard.applicability:
eSMTP defines an extension to the SMTP service, which allows an SMTP client to specify
that delivery status notifications (DSNs) should be generated under certain conditions,
whether such notifications should return the contents of the message, and
additional information, to be returned with a DSN, that allows the sender to identify both the recipient(s) for which the DSN was issued, and the transaction in which the original message was sent.

newstandard.title: MIME - Part 1: Format of Internet Message Bodies
newstandard.applicability: RFC 822:1982 defines a message representation protocol specifying considerable detail about US-ASCII message headers, and leaves the message content, or message body, as flat US-ASCII text. This set of documents, collectively called the Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions, or MIME, redefines the format of messages to allow for (1) textual message bodies in character sets other than US-ASCII, (2) an extensible set of different formats for non-textual message bodies, (3) multi-part message bodies, and (4) textual header information in character sets other than US-ASCII. Because RFC 822:1982 said so little about message bodies, these documents are largely orthogonal to (rather than a revision of) RFC 822:1982. The initial document (RFC 2045:1996) specifies the various headers used to describe the structure of MIME messages. The second document, RFC 2046:1996, defines the general structure of the MIME media typing system and defines an initial set of media types. The third document, RFC 2047:1996, describes extensions to RFC 822:1982 to allow non-US-ASCII text data in Internet mail header fields. The fourth document, RFC 2048:1996, specifies various IANA registration procedures for MIME-related facilities. The fifth and final document, RFC 2049:1996, describes MIME conformance criteria as well as providing some illustrative examples of MIME message formats, acknowledgements, and the bibliography.

newstandard.title: MIME - Part 4: Registration Procedures
newstandard.applicability: RFC 822:1982 defines a message representation protocol specifying considerable detail about US-ASCII message headers, and leaves the message content, or message body, as flat US-ASCII text. This set of documents, collectively called the Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions, or MIME, redefines the format of messages to allow for (1) textual message bodies in character sets other than US-ASCII, (2) an extensible set of different formats for non-textual message bodies, (3) multi-part message bodies, and (4) textual header information in character sets other than US-ASCII. Because RFC 822:1982 said so little about message bodies, these documents are largely orthogonal to (rather than a revision of) RFC 822:1982. The initial document (RFC 2045:1996) specifies the various headers used to describe the structure of MIME messages. The second document, RFC 2046:1996, defines the general structure of the MIME media typing system and defines an initial set of media types. The third document, RFC 2047:1996, describes extensions to RFC 822:1982 to allow non-US-ASCII text data in Internet mail header fields. The fourth document, RFC 2048:1996, specifies various IANA registration procedures for MIME-related facilities. The fifth and final document, RFC 2049:1996, describes MIME conformance criteria as well as providing some illustrative examples of MIME message formats, acknowledgements, and the bibliography.

newstandard.title: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP)
newstandard.applicability:
The DHCP provides configuration information to Internet hosts. There are several Internet protocols that address some parts of dynamic address allocation, such as BOOTP, and RARP. However, none of these is as flexible as DHCP, and although BOOTP is very similar, it does not address full dynamic address allocation. Dynamic address allocation is particularly important now that IPv4 addresses are relatively scarce. It facilitates renumbering when a site/organisation changes IP provider.
Configuration parameters and other control information are carried in tagged data items that are stored in the 'options' field of the DHCP message. The data items themselves are also called "options." This document specifies the current set of DHCP options. Future options will be specified in separate RFCs.

LDAP v3
newstandard.applicability: The Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP), developed for use over the Internet, is far more widely used than its X.500 equivalent DAP. LDAP support is becoming an integral component of a range of user platforms including Microsoft's Windows 98 and 2000. It is commonly available for UNIX environments as well as for use with X.400 and Internet based E-mail systems. LDAP is a variant of the full DAP and was originally intended by its creators to provide a lightweight complement to full DAP. Whilst DAP is much richer in functionality than LDAP, LDAP has gained considerable support in the commercial world. A number of vendors have made their proprietary directories LDAP-accessible and believe this to be a satisfactory approach for many of their customers. However, LDAP remains a simple access protocol only, and does not provide the protocols necessary for the full Directory service such as will be required by large military organisations, (note: this was one of the reasons why ACP133 currently mandates DAP). The use of LDAP in military systems is still subject to debate as there are both functional and security issues to be faced, (e.g. the US Defense Messaging System mandates DAP). However, LDAP performs a useful role in the provision of simple directory access from end-user networks

newstandard.title: Policy on Character Sets and Languages
newstandard.applicability:
RFC 2277:1998 mandates support of RFC 2279:1998 on the Internet.
UTF-8 uses all 8 bits of an octet, but has the quality of preserving the full US-ASCII backward compatibility.

newstandard.title: The mailto URL scheme
newstandard.applicability:
The Uniform Resource Locators (URLs) of the form “HTTP://[ ... ]”, relative resource pointers or “MAILTO:[Email address]” the syntax and semantics of formalized information for location and access of resources via the Internet.. The URL is used by e.g. web-browsers and the HTTP protocol.
The syntax of 'mailto' URLs is extended to allow creation of more RFC 2822 messages by allowing the URL to express additional header and body fields.
RFC 2396 describes a "superset" of operations that can be applied to URI. It consists of both a grammar and a description of basic functionality for URI. To understand what is a valid URI, both the grammar and the associated description have to be studied. Some of the functionality described is not applicable to all URI schemes, and some operations are only possible when certain media types are retrieved using the URI, regardless of the scheme used.

newstandard.title: Security Architecture for the Internet Protocol
newstandard.applicability:
IPsec is designed to provide interoperable, high quality, cryptographically-based security for IPv4 and IPv6. The set of security services offered includes access control, connectionless integrity, data origin authentication, protection against replays (a form of partial sequence integrity), confidentiality (encryption), and limited traffic flow confidentiality. These services are provided at the IP layer, offering protection for IP and/or upper layer protocols. These objectives are met through the use of two traffic security protocols, the Authentication Header (AH) and the Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP), and through the use of cryptographic key management procedures and protocols. The set of IPsec protocols employed in any context, and the ways in which they are employed, will be determined by the security and system requirements of users, applications, and/or sites/organizations.
IPsec provides security services at the IP layer by enabling a system to select required security protocols, determine the algorithm(s) to use for the service(s), and put in place any cryptographic keys required to provide the requested services. IPsec can be used to protect one or more "paths" between a pair of hosts, between a pair of security gateways, or between a security gateway and a host.
A basic and mandatory element of IPSec is the usage of Security Associations. A Security Association (SA) is a simplex "connection" that affords security services to the traffic carried by it. Security services are afforded to an SA by the use of AH, or ESP, but not both. If both AH and ESP protection is applied to a traffic stream, then two (or more) SAs are created to afford protection to the traffic stream. To secure typical, bi-directional communication between two hosts, or between two security gateways, two Security Associations (one in each direction) are required.
The key management protocol must be robust in order to handle public key generation for the Internet community at large and private key requirements for those private networks with that requirement. The Internet Security Association and Key Management Protocol (ISAKMP) defines the procedures for authenticating a communicating peer, creation and management of Security Associations, key generation techniques, and threat mitigation (e.g. denial of service and replay attacks). All of these are necessary to establish and maintain secure communications (via IP Security Service or any other security protocol) in an Internet environment.

IPsec provides security services at the IP layer by enabling a system to select required security protocols, determine the algorithm(s) to use for the service(s), and put in place any cryptographic keys required to provide the requested services. IPsec can be used to protect one or more "paths" between a pair of hosts, between a pair of security gateways, or between a security gateway and a host.
A basic and mandatory element of IPSec is the usage of Security Associations. A Security Association (SA) is a simplex "connection" that affords security services to the traffic carried by it. Security services are afforded to an SA by the use of AH, or ESP, but not both. If both AH and ESP protection is applied to a traffic stream, then two (or more) SAs are created to afford protection to the traffic stream. To secure typical, bi-directional communication between two hosts, or between two security gateways, two Security Associations (one in each direction) are required.
The key management protocol must be robust in order to handle public key generation for the Internet community at large and private key requirements for those private networks with that requirement. The Internet Security Association and Key Management Protocol (ISAKMP) defines the procedures for authenticating a communicating peer, creation and management of Security Associations, key generation techniques, and threat mitigation (e.g. denial of service and replay attacks). All of these are necessary to establish and maintain secure communications (via IP Security Service or any other security protocol) in an Internet environment.

eSMTP defines an extension to the SMTP service, which allows an SMTP client to specify
that delivery status notifications (DSNs) should be generated under certain conditions,
whether such notifications should return the contents of the message, and

newstandard.title: Coexistence between Version 1 and Version 2 of the Internet-standard Network Management Framework
newstandard.applicability: SNMPv2 is a protocol used to exchange management information between a Management-manager and Management-agents or another Management-manager. An agent manages an object (system, device, etc.) on behalf of the Manager. The basic responsibility of an agent is to keep information about the objects. The agent stores the information and then responds to a manager request or can generate unsolicited responses. By placing the brunt of the processing on the Manager side, able to limit the agent to a few easily deployed functions. As with CMIP, ASN.1 is used to define object classes, which are documented in the appropriate TCP/IP MIB (RFC 2011:1996 - 2013:1996), and in other more specialised MIBs that address such network components as Token Ring, FDDI and particular routers.

newstandard.title: S/MIME Version 3 Certificate Handling
newstandard.applicability: S/MIME (Secure/Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions), provides a method to send and receive secure MIME messages. Before using a public key to provide security services, the S/MIME agent must certify that the public key is valid. S/MIME agentsmust use PKIX certificates to validate public keys as described in the Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure (PKIX) Certificate and CRL Profile. S/MIME agents must meet the certificate processing requirements documented in this document in addition to those stated in X.509.

newstandard.title: Telnet Protocol Specification
newstandard.applicability:
TELNET provides remote log in to remote hosts by setting up and manipulating two simple data streams, one in each direction. TELNET was designed with scroll mode rather than page or foerm mode terminal in mind, although some page mode terminal properties can be negotiated. TELNET provides for full user authentication. TELNET is part of the Internet protocol suite (TCP/IP).
RFC 854 provides a fairly general, bi-directional, eight-bit byte oriented communications facility. Its primary goal is to allow a standard method of interfacing terminal devices and terminal-oriented processes to each other. It is envisioned that the protocol may also be used for terminal-terminal communication ("linking") and process-process communication (distributed computation).
RFC 855 specifies a method of option code assignment and standards for documentation of options. The individual responsible for assignment of option codes may waive the requirement for complete documentation for some cases of experimentation, but in general documentation will be required prior to code assignment. Options will be publicized by publishing their documentation as RFCs; inventors of options may, of course, publicize them in other ways as well.

newstandard.title: Bootstrap Protocol (BOOTP)
newstandard.applicability:
BOOTP describes an IP/UDP bootstrap protocol (BOOTP) which allows a diskless client machine to discover its own IP address, the address of a server host, and the name of a file to be loaded into memory and executed. The bootstrap operation can be thought of as consisting of TWO PHASES. This RFC describes the first phase, which could be labeled 'address determination and bootfile selection'. After this address and filename information is obtained, control passes to the second phase of the bootstrap where a file transfer occurs. The file transfer will typically use the TFTP protocol, since it is intended that both phases reside in PROM on the client. However BOOTP could also work with other protocols such as SFTP or FTP.
BOOTP can be used for bootstrapping diskless clients. It can provide a client with much more information than just its IP-address, and it can be used across routers, obviating the requirement to have a BOOTP server on every network. BOOTP runs on top of UDP, and works in conjunction with the Trivial File Transfer Protocol (TFTP) - a much simplified version of FTP - that uses UDP. BOOTP will be overtaken by DHCP.
Some aspects of the BOOTP protocol were rather loosely defined in its original specification. In particular, only a general description was provided for the behavior of "BOOTP relay agents" (originally called BOOTP forwarding agents"). The client behavior description also suffered in certain ways. This memo attempts to clarify and strengthen the specification in these areas.

newstandard.title: Simple feature access - Part 1: Common Architecture
newstandard.applicability:
ISO 19125-1 establishes a common architecture for geographic information and defines terms to use within the architecture. It also standardizes names and geometric definitions for Types for Geometry.
The purpose of part 2 of ISO 19125 is to define a standard Structured Query Language (SQL) schema that supports storage, retrieval, query and update of feature collections via the SQL Call-Level Interface (SQL/CLI) (ISO/IEC 9075-3:2008). A feature has both spatial and non-spatial attributes. Spatial attributes are geometry valued, and simple features are based on 2D geometry with linear interpolation between vertices. This part of ISO 19125 is dependent on the common architectural components defined in ISO 19125-1

newstandard.title: Simple feature access - Part 2: SQL option
newstandard.applicability:
ISO 19125-1 establishes a common architecture for geographic information and defines terms to use within the architecture. It also standardizes names and geometric definitions for Types for Geometry.
The purpose of part 2 of ISO 19125 is to define a standard Structured Query Language (SQL) schema that supports storage, retrieval, query and update of feature collections via the SQL Call-Level Interface (SQL/CLI) (ISO/IEC 9075-3:2008). A feature has both spatial and non-spatial attributes. Spatial attributes are geometry valued, and simple features are based on 2D geometry with linear interpolation between vertices. This part of ISO 19125 is dependent on the common architectural components defined in ISO 19125-1

newstandard.title: Representation of Names of Languages Part 2: Alpha-3
newstandard.applicability: This standard defines the codes representing the names of languages as two-letter lower-case symbols.

newstandard.title: FDDI Part 1: Token Ring Physical Layer Protocol (PHY)
newstandard.applicability: The above standard is applicable to systems requiring high-speed LAN services. FDDI provides a high bandwidth (100 Mbps) general-purpose interconnection among computers and peripheral equipment using optical fibre as the transmission medium in a dual-ring configuration. FDDI establishes the connection among many stations distributed over distances of several km in extent. FDDI is used for high capacity trunk links and is now increasingly being used to connect small systems on LANs.

newstandard.title: EDIFACT Part 1: Application level syntax rules: Syntax rules common to all parts, together with syntax service directories for each of the parts
newstandard.applicability: EDIFACT provides a mechanism for the electronic exchange of data that would be traditionally conveyed on paper documents. EDIFACT is typically used to transfer business documents such as purchase orders, invoices, and electronic funds transfer information. Electronic exchange of data using EDIFACT is governed according to established rules and formats. The data that are associated with each type of functional document, such as purchase order or invoice, are transmitted together as an electronic message. ITU-T X.435 addresses the transmission of EDI messages of X.400. Implementation of EDIFACT requires a family of interrelated standards which includes types of messages (or transaction sets), transmission envelopes, data elements, and short sequences to data elements called data segments.

newstandard.applicability: ACSE provides for connection-oriented and connection-less services and protocols to support establishment, maintenance and termination of application to application associations. A standard for an ACSE API has been developed by IEEE (see emerging standard OSI API Common Connection Management and Supporting Functions).

newstandard.title: System Management Part 1: Object Management Function
newstandard.applicability: Part 1 applies to an environment where two end-systems act in complementary roles, one end-system acting in the manager role while another end-system acts in the agent role. It establishes the requirements for the support of notification services for reporting the managed object creation, managed object deletion and changes in the values of attributes of managed objects. Part 2 establishes the models that relate the service and generic definitions required by the systems management and notification functions. Part 3 defines a set of generic relationships that may exist between managed objects and the services required for reading or modifying them or to notify the changes in a managed object's relationship. Part 16 identifies the set of requirements satisfied by the function, and provides a model for the behaviour of the management knowledge objects. Part 17 establishes user requirements for the service definition needed to support the change over function, and defines the services provided by the function. Part 18 includes software transfer, activation, de-activation, reversion, validation, and enquiry. Part 19 specifies management domain and policy functions. Part 20 specifies requirements for the time management function. Part 21 defines the Command Sequencer, which consists of generic definitions, services and functional units. Part 22 addresses response time monitoring.

newstandard.title: OSI Performance Management Part 11: Metric Objects and Attributes
newstandard.applicability: Part 11 specifies the model objects and algorithms required to monitor and control the workload of the management system. Part 12 specifies the model for establishing compliance requirements for testing the systems management function. Part 13 provides the ability to aggregate observed attribute values and provides statistical information about those values. Part 14 provides the ability to proactively test the health and operation of the management system. Part 15 provides for the scheduling of managed objects.

newstandard.title: OSI Fault Management Part 4: Alarm reporting function
newstandard.applicability: Part 4 defines a set of generic alarms that managed objects may send to a managing system. The alarms are used to notify of failures or abnormal situations. Part 5 defines the support managed objects and the services required to control the event reports exchanged among management systems. Part 6 defines a model for maintaining an ongoing record of activity of the operational and administrative state of the system.

newstandard.title: OSI Security Management Part 7: Security alarm reporting function
newstandard.applicability: Part 7 defines a set of generic security alarms that managed objects may send to a managing system. The alarms are used to notify of breaches in security. Part 8 defines the systems management functions of tracking and logging security events that occur in the management domain. Part 9 specifies the requirements for protecting management information from unauthorised creation, deletion, modification, or disclosure by means of OSI management operations.

newstandard.title: Security Framework in Open Systems Part 1: Overview
newstandard.applicability: This document defines the framework within which security services for open systems (i.e. database, distributed applications, ODP and OSI) are specified, and addresses data elements and sequences of operations (but not protocol elements) that are used to obtain security services. These security services may apply to the communicating entities of systems as well as to data exchanged between systems and to data managed by systems.

newstandard.title: ODP Part 1: Overview
newstandard.applicability: ODP relates to the interaction of both users and applications remotely with other computational resources (including other applications) held at different locations. The current ODP document defines a Reference Model of abstractions, functions, interfaces and modelling addressing five viewpoints of a distributed system: information, computation, engineering, enterprise and technology.

newstandard.title: JPEG Part 1: Requirements and Guidelines
newstandard.applicability: Joint Photographic Experts Group is the name of the committee that wrote the standard for Digital Compression and Coding of Continuous-Tone Still Images. JPEG is a formal standard defined by ISO/IEC 10918 and ITU-T Recommendation T.83. This standard sets out requirements and implementation guidelines for continuous-tone still image encoding and decoding processes, and for the coded representation of compressed image data. These processes and representations are intended to be generic, which is applicable to a broad range of applications for colour and grey-scale images within communication and computer systems. JPEG is lossy, meaning the image that comes out of decompression is not identical to what went in. The algorithm achieves much of its compression by exploiting known limitations of the human eye, notably, the fact that small colour details aren't perceived as well as small details of light and dark. Thus, JPEG is intended for compressing images that will be looked at by humans and not analysed by machine.

newstandard.title: MPEG-1 Part 1: Systems
newstandard.applicability:
Substantial computing power is required to encode MPEG data in real time. MPEG-1 is optimal for a variety of data rates up to 1.5 megabits per second.
MPEG-1 compression techniques are geared to asymmetric applications where the decompression process is extremely faster than the compression process. Applications making heavy use of this technology include electronic publishing, video games, and delivery of movies. It is also used extensively for downloading and uploading video on the World Wide Web. The shell format is interoperable across platforms and considered to be platform independent.

newstandard.title: IPI - Functional Specification, Part 1: Common Architecture for Imaging
newstandard.applicability: IPI is a functional specification and contains several language bindings for an API to imaging. The standard defines the data objects, primitive operations and a reference model. The API supplies the basic building blocks upon which applications requiring imaging functionality can be built within conventional, distributed and image-oriented computing environments. IIF gives the possibility to exchange graphical data, defined within the IPI environment, between different platforms.

newstandard.title: MPEG-2 Part 1: Systems
newstandard.applicability:
Generic Coding of Moving Pictures and Associated Audio is a formal standard defined by ISO 13818. MPEG-2 is required for generic compression coding of moving pictures and associated audio. MPEG-2 systems will form the infrastructure for delivery of audio and video in many industry sectors, including television distribution, visual telecommunications and a host of computer and multimedia applications.
MPEG-2 was initially intended for the recording and transmission of studio-quality motion video at bit rates in the order of 4 to 6 Mbps. The objective of MPEG-2 is to improve the quality of the image while maintaining the bit rate significantly below 10 Mbps. At the same time, more audio capabilities, such as multiple channels, have been included. The initial MPEG-2 standard has also been extended to support several HDTV formats. Its fields of application should be desktop videoconferencing and videophony

newstandard.title: MPEG-4 Part 1: Systems
newstandard.applicability:
The MPEG-4 standard addresses the coded representation of both natural and synthetic (computer-generated) audio and visual objects. MPEG 4 Systems was developed to provide the necessary facilities for specifying how such objects can be composed together in a MPEG-4 terminal to form complete scenes, as well as how they should be multiplexed for transmission or storage. The term terminal is used here in a generic sense, and of course includes computer programs hosted on general purpose computers.
The fundamental difference to MEG-1 and MPEG-2 systems is that MPEG-4 addresses the coded representation of audiovisual objects, both natural and synthetic. As a result, the Systems layer must address how these objects are composed together to form a scene (composition information or scene description), as well as how a user may interact with such objects. In addition, the object-based architecture necessitates changes in the way audiovisual information is multiplexed. In particular, it has a very flexible multiplexing structure and does not specify a transport layer facility as MPEG-2 did.

In addition, the object-based architecture necessitates changes in the way audiovisual information is multiplexed. In particular, it has a very flexible multiplexing structure and does not specify a transport layer facility as MPEG-2 did.

newstandard.title: Software Product Evaluation Part 1: General overview
newstandard.applicability: ISO 14598 defines product evaluation processes that clearly establish testing as a major activity that must be specified, planned, managed and executed, not just as a quick afterthought at the end of the software development life cycle.

newstandard.title: ITSEC/CC Part 1: Introduction and general model
ITSEC/CC Part 2: Security functional requirements
ITSEC/CC Part 3: Security assurance requirements
Bar code print quality test specification - Linear Symbols
newstandard.applicability:
Code 128 is one of the most recently adopted barcode symbologies and it's certainly the most complex at present. Code128 uses three separate character sets; Code128-A, Code128-B and Code128-C.
Code128-A - contains numberic characters, punctuation, upper-case letters and computer related codes.
Code128-B - is similar to Code128-A but doesn't include the special computer codes but includes lower-case.
Code128-C - is purely numberic. It may encosde numbers in pairs.
ISO 15416 describes a method for assessing the print quality of linear bar code symbols, based on the analysis of a scan reflectance profile, i.e. the plot of reflectance versus distance as a sampling aperture is passed over the symbol from one end to another. It defines a reference optical arrangement for making measurements, the parameters to be assessed, the method of assigning quality grades to the measured parameter values and the means of deriving an overall symbol grade. It provides guidance on possible causes of low grades. It is intended for use either to predict the likely performance of a bar code symbol when scanned or as a tool for process control in the printing of bar code symbols.

newstandard.title: JPEG 2000 Part 1: Core coding system
newstandard.applicability: Joint Photographic Experts Group is the name of the committee that wrote the standard for Digital Compression and Coding. JPEG is a formal standard defined by ISO/IEC 15444 and ITU-T Recommendation T.800. This standard defines a set of lossless (bit-preserving) and lossy compression methods for coding continuous-tone, bi-level, gray-scale, or colour digital still images.

newstandard.title: RELAX NG Specification
newstandard.applicability:
RELAX NG is a simple schema language for XML, based on [RELAX] and [TREX]. A RELAX NG schema specifies a pattern for the structure and content of an XML document. A RELAX NG schema is itself an XML document.
RELAX NG deals with XML documents representing both schemas and instances through an abstract data model. XML documents representing schemas and instances must be well-formed in conformance with [XML 1.0] and must conform to the constraints of [XML Namespaces].

newstandard.title: Transport Services
newstandard.applicability:
The Transport Services offer the following features to a Transport Service User:
the means to establish one or more end-to-end transport connections to another transport-user.
request and negotiate and agree a quality of service for the Transport Connection.
transferring (expedited) data over a Transport Connection.

newstandard.title: Connection-oriented Transport protocol
newstandard.applicability:
The Transport Services offer the following features to a Transport Service User:
the means to establish one or more end-to-end transport connections to another transport-user.
request and negotiate and agree a quality of service for the Transport Connection.
transferring (expedited) data over a Transport Connection.

newstandard.title: CO/CL Session services
newstandard.applicability: Session Services and Protocols provide the means for organised and synchronised exchange of data between co-operating Session Services users.

newstandard.title: CO Session protocol
newstandard.applicability: Session Services and Protocols provide the means for organised and synchronised exchange of data between co-operating Session Services users.

newstandard.title: Connectionless Transport protocol
newstandard.applicability:
The Transport Services offer the following features to a Transport Service User:
the means to establish one or more end-to-end transport connections to another transport-user.
request and negotiate and agree a quality of service for the Transport Connection.
transferring (expedited) data over a Transport Connection.

newstandard.title: ODA Part 1: Introduction and General Principles
newstandard.applicability:
This standard permits the interchange of documents between co-operating tools in office systems by providing a common understanding of the structure of documents. For the ODA standard, a document is a structured amount of text, graphics, and scanned images, is characterised by its content (logical structure) and its internal organisation (layout structure), and can be grouped into a document class getting together similar documents such as report, letter, memo.
Part 5 (ODIF) is an ASN.1 based presentation, which specifies the interchange format for ODA documents.
Office Document Language (ODL) is the Standard Generalised Mark-up Language (SGML) encoding for ODA documents to enter an SGML database or publishing environment

newstandard.title: CGM Part 1: Functional Specification
newstandard.applicability:
Computer Graphics Metafile is a formal standard defined by ISO/IEC 8632 and FIPS 128-1. CGM is a computer- and operating system independent interchange format. There are elements to represent both geometric graphics content (e.g., circles, polygons) and raster graphics content (e.g., pixel arrays). An element's appearance can be affected by attributes (e.g., line cap, line join, mitre limit, fill pattern). Several colour models (RGB, CMYK, etc.) are supported. CGM is widely used in the publishing industry.
The elements contained in a CGM file represent a wide range of picture types. The elements are split into functional groups that delimit major structures: (1) define the representations used within the metafile; (2) control the display of the picture; (3) perform basic drawing functions; (4) control the attributes of the basic drawing actions; and (5) provide access to non-standard devices.

newstandard.title: ASN.1 Part 1: Specification of basic notation
newstandard.applicability: Abstract Syntax Notation One (ASN.1) describes data types in a machine-independent manner, thus freeing data representation from machine restrictions and inner representation. By applying the Basic Encoding Rules (BER) mechanism to the abstract representation of the data, the data is translated either for machine storage or transmission; this is the so-called transfer syntax.

newstandard.title: 8-Bit Code Set Part 1: Latin Alphabet No. 1 (Europe/Latin America)
newstandard.applicability:
This standard specifies a set of up to 191 graphic characters by means of a single 8-Bit byte.
The ISO 8859 charsets were designed in the mid-1980s by the European Computer Manufacturer's Association (ECMA) and endorsed by the International Standards Organisation (ISO).The ISO 8859 charsets are not even remotely as complete as the truly great Unicode but they have been around and usable for quite a while (first registered Internet charsets for use with MIME) and have already offered a major improvement over the plain 7bit US-ASCII.

newstandard.title: (X.212), Data Link Service Definition for OSI
newstandard.applicability: The above standards are applicable to systems requiring data link services. Note that the X.21 (synchronous digital interface) and X.21 bis (synchronous V-Series modem interface) Physical layer standards typically would be used to support ISO/IEC 7776 (X.25 LAP B).

newstandard.title: ROSE Part 1: Model, Notation and Services
newstandard.applicability: ROSE is a vehicle for supporting distributed interactive applications. The basic interaction with a remote object is an operation that is similar to a procedure call in a programming language. Remote Operations is asynchronous, in case an invoking client need not wait for a response before invoking another operation, or synchronous, in case the performer needs to report a result before the invoker is allowed to invoke another.

newstandard.title: Database languages - SQL - Part 1: Framework
newstandard.applicability: ISO/IEC 9075 defines the SQL language. The scope of the SQL language is the definition of data structure and the operations on data stored in that structure. Parts 1, 2 and 11 encompass the minimum requirements of the language. Others parts define extensions.

newstandard.title: FDDI Part 13: Conformance Test Protocol Implementation Conformance Statement (CT-PICS) Proforma
newstandard.applicability: The above standard is applicable to systems requiring high-speed LAN services. FDDI provides a high bandwidth (100 Mbps) general-purpose interconnection among computers and peripheral equipment using optical fibre as the transmission medium in a dual-ring configuration. FDDI establishes the connection among many stations distributed over distances of several km in extent. FDDI is used for high capacity trunk links and is now increasingly being used to connect small systems on LANs.

FDDI is used for high capacity trunk links and is now increasingly being used to connect small systems on LANs.

newstandard.title: Font Information Interchange Part 1: Architecture
newstandard.applicability:
This standard, as a whole, specifies the architecture of font resources and the formats for font interchange amongst information processing systems. It also defines the architecture and formats that can be used to construct font references in general electronic document interchange.
Font resources represented using the architecture and interchange formats, as defined in parts 1 and 2, are used in various document-processing environments in which ASN.1 or SGML parsing algorithms are recognised. The encoding of font resource information, as defined in part 3, is specified in both ASN.1 and SGML representations for consistent generation of font resources for use in these processing environments

newstandard.title: CGI Part 1: Overview, Profiles and Conformance
newstandard.applicability: Computer Graphics Interfacing Techniques includes in part 1 a reference model, the relationship to other standards, and profiles. It establishes the framework for all the parts of ISO/IEC 9636. Part 2 describes those functions of the interface concerned with virtual device management, coordinate space control, and error control. Part 3 describes those functions of the interface concerned with output primitives and associated attributes and controls for creating graphical pictures. Part 4 defines those functions of the interface concerned with the creation, modification, and manipulation of graphic pictures using segments. Part 5 Defines those functions of the interface concerned with obtaining graphical and non-graphical input from a virtual device. Defines also functions to support echoing of input operations on separate virtual devices. Part 6: describes those functions of the interface concerned with creating, modifying, retrieving, and displaying portions of an image stored as pixel data.

newstandard.title: Commitment Concurrency and Recovery (CCR) - services
newstandard.applicability: CCR supplies applications with more fault tolerant association services than ACSE. CCR 'adds' to the ACSE services (ACSE does leave a system with ambiguous results when a system crashes and lack of co-ordination could produce inconsistent results) the concept of commitment. The master CCR party asks the subordinate CCR party for a commitment to perform a task before the call for executing the task is made. This allows for both master and subordinates to keep record of the task.

newstandard.title: MPEG-2 Part 5: Software simulation
newstandard.applicability:
Generic Coding of Moving Pictures and Associated Audio is a formal standard defined by ISO 13818. MPEG-2 is required for generic compression coding of moving pictures and associated audio. MPEG-2 systems will form the infrastructure for delivery of audio and video in many industry sectors, including television distribution, visual telecommunications and a host of computer and multimedia applications.
MPEG-2 was initially intended for the recording and transmission of studio-quality motion video at bit rates in the order of 4 to 6 Mbps. The objective of MPEG-2 is to improve the quality of the image while maintaining the bit rate significantly below 10 Mbps. At the same time, more audio capabilities, such as multiple channels, have been included. The initial MPEG-2 standard has also been extended to support several HDTV formats. Its fields of application should be desktop videoconferencing and videophony

newstandard.title: Numbering standard for ISDN era
newstandard.applicability: The above standards are applicable to systems requiring digital, circuit switched services. The ISDN standards cover a telecommunications area analogous to the existing voice telephony network but operating digital signalling and capable of much higher data rates. ISDN circuits offer the user the ability to dial another ISDN user (using ITU-T E.164 ISDN numbering standard) and to use the enhanced data capacity in very flexible ways. ISDN is best viewed as a data pipeline which, once a connection has been established between two users, may operate a variety of protocols and carry all types of data, including voice and image. Although ISDN was originally implemented in different ways in Europe there is now a standard, Euro-ISDN, created by the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI), to which all European nations have subscribed and which now covers most of the population of Europe. The Basic user-network interface offers the user two 64kbps 'B' or Bearer channels. These may be used individually for conventional data communications or may be grouped together to give an aggregate data capacity of 128kbps for applications like restricted video. There is also a 16kbps 'D' channel which the ISDN network uses to control the operation of the 'B' channels. Euro-ISDN specifies the use of 64kbps circuit switching or 3.1kHz speech over 'B' channels but will progress to cover X.31 (X.25 over ISDN) over 'B' and 'D' channels, along with 7 KHz speech. In fact, some European PTTs are already offering an X.25 packet switching service to ISDN subscribers based on the 'D' channel. The Primary rate user-interface offers the subscriber thirty 64kbps 'B' channels and, as with the Basic interface, these may be operated singly or grouped together to service users at the termination point. The Primary rate also features a 64kbps 'D' control channel. Corporate subscribers with more than just a small number of users will be more likely to use a Primary rate interface. The thirty 'B' channels can aggregate up to a 2.048Mbps connection.

newstandard.title: Vocabulary of Terms for broadband aspects of ISDN
newstandard.applicability: The above standards are applicable to systems requiring high capacity, digital, circuit-switched services. Broadband ISDN extends the narrow band ISDN concept of end-to-end user data transfer into the very high capacities offered by fibre optics. Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM), with its concept of fast switching of small cells, has become the choice of implementation of B-ISDN.

newstandard.title: Broadband aspects of ISDN
newstandard.applicability: The above standards are applicable to systems requiring high capacity, digital, circuit-switched services. Broadband ISDN extends the narrow band ISDN concept of end-to-end user data transfer into the very high capacities offered by fibre optics. Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM), with its concept of fast switching of small cells, has become the choice of implementation of B-ISDN.

newstandard.title: B-ISDN ATM Layer Specification
newstandard.applicability: The above standards are applicable to systems requiring fast packet switching services. ATM is a cell relay switching technique similar to Frame Relay. ATM is intended for use with Broadband-ISDN (B-ISDN) and will eventually offer transmission speeds of between 155 Mbits/s and 2.4 Gbits/s over such emergent technologies as Synchronous Digital Hierarchy (SDH) in Europe and Synchronous Optical Network (SONET) in the USA. ATM is built on the use of a standard sized packet, or cell, of 53 bytes. The user traffic volume offered by this technology will make the simultaneous transmission of data, voice and video a practical proposition and will probably obsolete much of today's technology in due course.

newstandard.title: B-ISDN Adaption Layer (AAL) Specification

The thirty 'B' channels can aggregate up to a 2.048Mbps connection.

newstandard.title: DSS1 ISDN User interface network Data Link layer
newstandard.applicability: The above standards are applicable to systems requiring digital, circuit switched services. The ISDN standards cover a telecommunications area analogous to the existing voice telephony network but operating digital signalling and capable of much higher data rates. ISDN circuits offer the user the ability to dial another ISDN user (using ITU-T E.164 ISDN numbering standard) and to use the enhanced data capacity in very flexible ways. ISDN is best viewed as a data pipeline which, once a connection has been established between two users, may operate a variety of protocols and carry all types of data, including voice and image. Although ISDN was originally implemented in different ways in Europe there is now a standard, Euro-ISDN, created by the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI), to which all European nations have subscribed and which now covers most of the population of Europe. The Basic user-network interface offers the user two 64kbps 'B' or Bearer channels. These may be used individually for conventional data communications or may be grouped together to give an aggregate data capacity of 128kbps for applications like restricted video. There is also a 16kbps 'D' channel which the ISDN network uses to control the operation of the 'B' channels. Euro-ISDN specifies the use of 64kbps circuit switching or 3.1kHz speech over 'B' channels but will progress to cover X.31 (X.25 over ISDN) over 'B' and 'D' channels, along with 7 KHz speech. In fact, some European PTTs are already offering an X.25 packet switching service to ISDN subscribers based on the 'D' channel. The Primary rate user-interface offers the subscriber thirty 64kbps 'B' channels and, as with the Basic interface, these may be operated singly or grouped together to service users at the termination point. The Primary rate also features a 64kbps 'D' control channel. Corporate subscribers with more than just a small number of users will be more likely to use a Primary rate interface. The thirty 'B' channels can aggregate up to a 2.048Mbps connection.

newstandard.title: Standardization of group 3 facsimile terminals for document transmission
newstandard.applicability:
These are formal standards for Facsimile Coding Schemes and Coding Control Functions for Group 3 and Group 4 Facsimile Apparatus published by ITU. These recommendations specify interchange of optically scanned engineering drawings and pages of technical publications, and define directives to compress raster graphics in order to reduce file size and transmission time. The compression method is bit-preserving, which means it is distortion-less and that the final decoded image is identical to the original.
The T4 recommendation is applicable to group 3 telecopy machines while the T6 recommendation is applicable to group 4. Technically, the biggest difference is that T6 has better compression capabilities than T4. Most fax products are based on these standards.

newstandard.title: MS-WIN32 Programming Reference
newstandard.applicability: In contrast to standards like POSIX.1 or POSIX.2 WIN32 is more a complete set of API's to cover the needs of the whole system and not only part of the system, like in this case the Operating System. It deals with API's and KPI's for a wide spectrum of functions like Object Linking and Embedding, Remote Procedure Calls, Multi Media, Presentation (GUI), System Calls, specialised Graphic Operations (OpenGL), System Messaging (MAPI), Telephone and PEN interface API's. Also included in the full WIN32 functionality is a set of functions to deal with Multiprocessing. If WIN32 is used natively, without the subsets, it also includes parts of the POSIX.1 functionality; the part of WIN32 that deals with POSIX.1 functions is ruled to be POSIX.1 compliant. That means that a product like Windows 2000, that is built with this function, 'can' be ruled POSIX.1 compliant. This 'does not' mean that WIN32 is POSIX.1 compliant, but allows the build up of a POSIX subsystem. To clarify this special aspect of WIN32, a product, in this case Windows 2000 will be used as an example. Among the requirements, met by Windows 2000, are next to portability, multiple processor capability, distributability and security compliance with the POSIX.1 standard, Windows 2000 provides only a POSIX-subsystem. Subsystems are the basic architecture elements of Windows 2000. They are servers for the system-calls of the application of the specific subsystem. When the user starts a POSIX application, WIN32 based Windows 2000 initiates a new process and passes it to the POSIX-subsystem. The program calls a subsystem with a 'Local Procedure Call' by means of the POSIX-library - a server 'Demon' that is started up together with Windows 2000. The latter translates the calls to operating system access. After all an application stays caught in its own world, because POSIX-applications cannot place calls to the WIN32 subsystems. WIN32 offers over 1500 API's to cover all the needs of application developers.

newstandard.title: TACOMS: Head STANAG
newstandard.applicability:
The aim of these NATO standardisation agreements (STANAGs) is to provide the standards for communications interoperability in the Land Combat Zone Post 2000.
The TACOMS standards have been designed to meet the TACOMS tactical communication system operational requirements in compliance with MC-337: NATO Post 2000 Military Operational Requirements for the Land Combat Zone.
They cover all communication subsystems that are to be deployed on a battlefield to fulfil communication interoperability required by the tactical operation:
LAS: Local Area Subsystem, responsible for the internal Headquarters communications,
WAS: Wide Area Subsystem, responsible for the long range communications,
MS: Mobile Subsystem, responsible for the communications required by the mobile users connected by radio equipment,
SMCS: System Management and Control Subsystem, responsible for the deployment and supervision tasks.
TACOMS Post 2000 was a standardisation initiative between 13 NATO Nations. Its aim is to improve interoperability between tactical land communication systems in future land based coalition operations.
The TACOMS approach is to provide a communications interoperability standard for network centric operations performed by NATO multi-national forces involved in a joint deployment. TACOMS is able to provide the communication interoperability standard for the NATO Response Force (NRF) initiative.
Legacy tactical networks deployed during the past 30 years are based on several different switching and transmission technologies, and provide different sets of native network services to users.
Interoperability with users in different networks (including legacy tactical) is currently achieved by means of gateways with an agreed minimum set of services.
This legacy gateway concept (as in STANAG 4206) provides interoperability with a very limited set of services. There is no user mobility, very limited bandwidth and limited packet data capability.
The TACOMS standards allow national systems to inter-operate with a maximum of coalition operational efficiency, while the individual national network elements maintain their value. The TACOMS standards also specify gateways to provide interoperability with external non-TACOMS compliant networks, such as civilian, military strategic and legacy tactical networks.
The standardisation in TACOMS fully specifies the interfaces between nations to enable interoperability, but does not mandate a technology to be used within the national systems.
The TACOMS concept is based on a Service Oriented Architecture and has been defined as follows:
An extensive set of end-to-end user and network services is defined for TACOMS.
Each nation chooses independently how and with what technology they will implement these user and network services internally in their network elements.
TACOMS standardised Interoperability Points (IOP) and User Terminal Access Points (UTAP) are provided at the edges of these elements, to interconnect them with other nations? network elements or user terminals.
The network elements are then defined in TACOMS with performance characteristics and transfer functions allowing multinational performance guarantees through Service Level Specifications (SLS) and their corresponding instances, the Service Level Agreements (SLA).
TACOMS External Network Access Points (ENAP) to provide connectivity to civilian and military networks.
The TACOMS standards define the interoperability requirements for a network consisting of interconnected national elements, in such a way that it appears to the users as one network, fulfilling all defined requirements for user services and their defined Quality of Service (QoS), capacity, mobility, robustness, security, etc.

The standardisation in TACOMS fully specifies the interfaces between nations to enable interoperability, but does not mandate a technology to be used within the national systems.
The TACOMS concept is based on a Service Oriented Architecture and has been defined as follows:
An extensive set of end-to-end user and network services is defined for TACOMS.
Each nation chooses independently how and with what technology they will implement these user and network services internally in their network elements.
TACOMS standardised Interoperability Points (IOP) and User Terminal Access Points (UTAP) are provided at the edges of these elements, to interconnect them with other nations? network elements or user terminals.
The network elements are then defined in TACOMS with performance characteristics and transfer functions allowing multinational performance guarantees through Service Level Specifications (SLS) and their corresponding instances, the Service Level Agreements (SLA).
TACOMS External Network Access Points (ENAP) to provide connectivity to civilian and military networks.
The TACOMS standards define the interoperability requirements for a network consisting of interconnected national elements, in such a way that it appears to the users as one network, fulfilling all defined requirements for user services and their defined Quality of Service (QoS), capacity, mobility, robustness, security, etc.

newstandard.title: TACOMS: Connectionless Network Protocols
newstandard.applicability:
The aim of these NATO standardisation agreements (STANAGs) is to provide the standards for communications interoperability in the Land Combat Zone Post 2000.
The TACOMS standards have been designed to meet the TACOMS tactical communication system operational requirements in compliance with MC-337: NATO Post 2000 Military Operational Requirements for the Land Combat Zone.
They cover all communication subsystems that are to be deployed on a battlefield to fulfil communication interoperability required by the tactical operation:
LAS: Local Area Subsystem, responsible for the internal Headquarters communications,
WAS: Wide Area Subsystem, responsible for the long range communications,
MS: Mobile Subsystem, responsible for the communications required by the mobile users connected by radio equipment,
SMCS: System Management and Control Subsystem, responsible for the deployment and supervision tasks.
TACOMS Post 2000 was a standardisation initiative between 13 NATO Nations. Its aim is to improve interoperability between tactical land communication systems in future land based coalition operations.
The TACOMS approach is to provide a communications interoperability standard for network centric operations performed by NATO multi-national forces involved in a joint deployment. TACOMS is able to provide the communication interoperability standard for the NATO Response Force (NRF) initiative.
Legacy tactical networks deployed during the past 30 years are based on several different switching and transmission technologies, and provide different sets of native network services to users.
Interoperability with users in different networks (including legacy tactical) is currently achieved by means of gateways with an agreed minimum set of services.
This legacy gateway concept (as in STANAG 4206) provides interoperability with a very limited set of services. There is no user mobility, very limited bandwidth and limited packet data capability.
The TACOMS standards allow national systems to inter-operate with a maximum of coalition operational efficiency, while the individual national network elements maintain their value. The TACOMS standards also specify gateways to provide interoperability with external non-TACOMS compliant networks, such as civilian, military strategic and legacy tactical networks.

Each nation chooses independently how and with what technology they will implement these user and network services internally in their network elements.
TACOMS standardised Interoperability Points (IOP) and User Terminal Access Points (UTAP) are provided at the edges of these elements, to interconnect them with other nations? network elements or user terminals.
The network elements are then defined in TACOMS with performance characteristics and transfer functions allowing multinational performance guarantees through Service Level Specifications (SLS) and their corresponding instances, the Service Level Agreements (SLA).
TACOMS External Network Access Points (ENAP) to provide connectivity to civilian and military networks.
The TACOMS standards define the interoperability requirements for a network consisting of interconnected national elements, in such a way that it appears to the users as one network, fulfilling all defined requirements for user services and their defined Quality of Service (QoS), capacity, mobility, robustness, security, etc.

newstandard.title: eXtensible Access Control Markup Language core specification v2.0:2008
newstandard.applicability: The security policy of a large enterprise has many elements and many points of enforcement. Elements of policy may be managed by the Information Systems department, by Human Resources, by the Legal department and by the Finance department. And the policy may be enforced by the extranet, mail, WAN and remote-access systems; platforms which inherently implement a permissive security policy. The current practice is to manage the configuration of each point of enforcement independently in order to implement the security policy as accurately as possible. Consequently, it is an expensive and unreliable proposition to modify the security policy. And, it is virtually impossible to obtain a consolidated view of the safeguards in effect throughout the enterprise to enforce the policy. At the same time, there is increasing pressure on corporate and government executives from consumers, shareholders and regulators to demonstrate "best practice" in the protection of the information assets of the enterprise and its customers. For these reasons, there is a pressing need for a common language for expressing security policy. If implemented throughout an enterprise, a common policy language allows the enterprise to manage the enforcement of all the elements of its security policy in all the components of its information systems. Managing security policy may include some or all of the following steps: writing, reviewing, testing, approving, issuing, combining, analyzing, modifying, withdrawing, retrieving and enforcing policy. XML is a natural choice as the basis for the common security-policy language, due to the ease with which its syntax and semantics can be extended to accommodate the unique requirements of this application, and the widespread support that it enjoys from all the main platform and tool vendors.

newstandard.title: RELAX NG Compact Syntax
newstandard.applicability:
RELAX NG is a simple schema language for XML, based on [RELAX] and [TREX]. A RELAX NG schema specifies a pattern for the structure and content of an XML document. A RELAX NG schema is itself an XML document.
RELAX NG deals with XML documents representing both schemas and instances through an abstract data model. XML documents representing schemas and instances must be well-formed in conformance with [XML 1.0] and must conform to the constraints of [XML Namespaces].

newstandard.title: Web Services Security: SOAP Message Security V1.0
newstandard.applicability:
WS-Security describes enhancements to SOAP messaging to provide quality of protection through message integrity, message confidentiality, and single message authentication. These mechanisms can be used to accommodate a wide variety of security models and encryption technologies.
WS-Security also provides a general-purpose mechanism for associating security tokens with messages. No specific type of security token is required by WS-Security. It is designed to be extensible (e.g. support multiple security token formats). For example, a client might provide proof of identity and proof that they have a particular business certification.
Additionally, WS-Security describes how to encode binary security tokens. Specifically, the specification describes how to encode X.509 certificates and Kerberos tickets as well as how to include opaque encrypted keys. It also includes extensibility mechanisms that can be used to further describe the characteristics of the credentials that are included with a message.

newstandard.title: X/Open Motif Toolkit API
newstandard.applicability: The Common Desktop Environment (CDE) is an integrated graphical user interface for open systems desktop computing. It delivers a single, standard graphical interface for the management of data and files (the graphical desktop) and applications. CDE's primary benefits -- deriving from ease-of-use, consistency, configurabbility, portabiility, distributed design, and protection of investment in today's applications -- make open systems desktop computers as easy to use as PCs, but with the added power of local and network resources available at the click of a mouse.

newstandard.title: Document Object Model (DOM) Level 2 Core Specification
newstandard.applicability:
The specification defines the Document Object Model Level 2 HTML, a platform- and language-neutral interface that allows programs and scripts to dynamically access and update the content and structure of HTML 4.01 and XHTML 1.0 documents. The Document Object Model Level 2 HTML builds on the Document Object Model Level 2 Core and is not backward compatible with DOM Level 1 HTML. The goals of the HTML-specific DOM API are:
(1) to specialize and add functionality that relates specifically to HTML documents and elements.
(2) to address issues of backwards compatibility with the DOM Level 0.
(3) to provide convenience mechanisms, where appropriate, for common and frequent operations on HTML documents.
The key differences between the core DOM and the HTML application of DOM is that the HTML Document Object Model exposes a number of convenience methods and properties that are consistent with the existing models and are more appropriate to script writers. In many cases, these enhancements are not applicable to a general DOM because they rely on the presence of a predefined DTD. The transitional or frameset DTD for HTML 4.01, or the XHTML 1.0 DTDs are assumed. Interoperability between implementations is only guaranteed for elements and attributes that are specified in the HTML 4.01 and XHTML 1.0 DTDs.

newstandard.title: Document Object Model (DOM) Level 3 Core Specification
newstandard.applicability:
This specification defines the Document Object Model Core Level 3, a platform- and language-neutral interface that allows programs and scripts to dynamically access and update the content, structure and style of documents. The Document Object Model Core Level 3 builds on the Document Object Model Core Level 2 [DOM Level 2 Core].
This version enhances DOM Level 2 Core by completing the mapping between DOM and the XML Information Set [XML Information Set], including the support for XML Base [XML Base], adding the ability to attach user information to DOM Nodes or to bootstrap a DOM implementation, providing mechanisms to resolve namespace prefixes or to manipulate "ID" attributes, giving to type information, etc.

newstandard.title: SOAP Version 1.2 Part 0: Primer
newstandard.applicability: SOAP is a lightweight protocol for exchange of information in a decentralized, distributed environment. It is an XML based protocol that consists of three parts: an envelope that defines a framework for describing what is in a message and how to process it, a set of encoding rules for expressing instances of application-defined datatypes, and a convention for representing remote procedure calls and responses. SOAP can potentially be used in combination with a variety of other protocols; however, the only bindings defined in this document describe how to use SOAP in combination with HTTP and HTTP Extension Framework.

newstandard.title: XML Schema Part 0: Primer
newstandard.applicability:
XSD (XML Schema Definition) specifies how to formally describe the elements in an Extensible Markup Language (XML) document. This description can be used to verify that each item of content in a document adheres to the description of the element in which the content is to be placed.
In general, a schema is an abstract representation of an object's characteristics and relationship to other objects. An XML schema represents the interrelationship between the attributes and elements of an XML object (for example, a document or a portion of a document). To create a schema for a document, you analyze its structure, defining each structural element as you encounter it. For example, within a schema for a document describing a Web site, you would define a Web site element, a Web page element, and other elements that describe possible content divisions within any page on that site. Just as in XML and HTML, elements are defined within a set of tags

newstandard.title: XPointer element() Scheme
newstandard.applicability:
This specification defines the XML Pointer Language (XPointer), the language to be used as the basis for a fragment identifier for any URI reference that locates a resource whose Internet media type is one of text/xml, application/xml, text/xml-external-parsed-entity, or application/xml-external-parsed-entity.
XPointer, which is based on the XML Path Language (XPath), supports addressing into the internal structures of XML documents. It allows for examination of a hierarchical document structure and choice of its internal parts based on various properties, such as element types, attribute values, character content, and relative position.
